Detailed Description

The base class of all physical robotic classes.

The class PhysicalObject is the base class of all physical robotic classes (e.g. Manipulator, Gripper, Puma 560). It defines a generic interface that is common to all of the physical robotic classes. This allows to perform an operation on all physical objects (e.g. create the VRML representation for the SceneViewer).

Specifically, PhysicalObject defines:

  • 3D model creation, update and appearance
  • Specification of the object position and orientation
  • Simulation mode functionality

Example Program: 

//======================================================================== 
// Project: Robotic Platform
// ---------------------------------------------------------------------- 
// Package: Core Classes
// Authors: Markus Loffler
// Start Date: Sun Nov 19 21:08:21 utc 2000
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------  
// File: PhysicalObject.t.cpp
// Example program for the class PhysicalObject.
//
// This example program demonstrates the creation of a new class,
// derived from the class PhysicalObject. Then, different functions
// of the class PhysicalObject are illustrated.
//========================================================================  
 

// ----- Standard Libaries -----
#include <iostream.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <conio.h>

// ----- QRTS Libraries -----

// ----- Project Includes -----
#include "RoboticPlatform.hpp"
#include "PhysicalObject.hpp"
#include "QWidgets.hpp"
#include "ObjectManager.hpp"
#include "TypeInfoT.hpp"

 
//======================================================================== 
// class Motor
// ---------------------------------------------------------------
// This class implements a motor - the body with a rotating shaft.
//========================================================================  
 
class Motor : public PhysicalObject
{
 private:
  typedef PhysicalObject Parent;
  
 public:
  // ----- Constructor and destructor -----
  Motor (const TypeInfo *parent);
  Motor (const char *objectName);
  Motor (int i = 1);
  ~Motor ();
  
  // ----- Virtual functions defined in the class RoboticObject -----
  virtual const TypeInfo *getTypeInfo() const { return &s_typeInfo; }
  virtual void startShutdown();
  virtual int getShutdownProgress();
  virtual int getNumCommands() const;
  virtual const char *getCommandName(int i) const;
  virtual void doCommand(int i);
  virtual int getNumAdditionalThreads();
  virtual void *thread(int num);
  virtual void createControlPanel(bool realizeFlag = true);
  virtual void updateGUI();
  
  // ----- Virtual functions defined in the class PhysicalObject -----
  virtual void create3DModel();

  void setMotorSpeed(double speed) { d_motorSpeed = speed; }
  double getMotorSpeed() { return d_motorSpeed; }
      
 private:
  double d_motorSpeed;
  double d_motorPosition;
  double d_startShutdownMotorSpeed;

  static const TypeInfoT<Motor> s_typeInfo;
  CLabel *d_positionLabel;
  CProgress *d_velocityProgress;
  CArc *d_positionArc;
};
 
const TypeInfoT<Motor> Motor::s_typeInfo("Motor", "PhysicalObject");


//======================================================================== 
// Motor::Motor
//========================================================================  

Motor::Motor(const TypeInfo *parent)
  : Parent(&s_typeInfo),
    d_motorSpeed(0),
    d_motorPosition(0)
{
}


Motor::Motor(int i)
  : Parent(&s_typeInfo),
    d_motorSpeed(0),
    d_motorPosition(0)
{
  init(i);
}


Motor::Motor(const char *objectName)
  : Parent(&s_typeInfo),
    d_motorSpeed(0),
    d_motorPosition(0)
{
  init(objectName);
}


//======================================================================== 
// Motor::~Motor
//========================================================================  

Motor::~Motor()
{
  exit();
}


//======================================================================== 
// Motor::createControlPanel
//========================================================================  

void Motor::createControlPanel(bool realizeFlag)
{
  if (isControlPanelOpen())
    return;

  Parent::createControlPanel(false);

  RoboticPlatform::lockPhoton();
    
  addControlPanelSeparator();
  
  CGroup *group = new CGroup(d_controlPanelGroup);
  group->setHorizontalOrientation();
  group->setVerticalAlignCenter();
  group->setSpacing(10, 0);

  new CLabel(group, "Motor Position");

  d_positionArc = new CArc(group, 0, 0, 20, 20);
  PhPoint_t pointArray[2] = { 0, 0, 20, 20 };
  d_positionArc->setPoints(pointArray, 2);
  d_positionArc->setArcTypePie();
  d_positionArc->setInsideColor(0xF0F0C0);
  
  d_positionLabel = new CLabel(group, "        ");
  d_positionLabel->setFillColor(Pg_WHITE);
  d_positionLabel->highlight(1, 0, 0);

  new CLabel(group, "   Motor Speed");
  d_velocityProgress = new CProgress(group, 0, 0, 140, 12);
  d_velocityProgress->setMinimum(0);
  d_velocityProgress->setMaximum(200);
  d_velocityProgress->setNumberOfDivisions(100);
  
  if (realizeFlag)
    d_controlPanelWindow->realize();
    
  RoboticPlatform::unlockPhoton();
}

 
//======================================================================== 
// Motor::updateGUI
//========================================================================  

void Motor::updateGUI()
{
  Parent::updateGUI();

  if (!d_controlPanelWindow)
    return; 

  RoboticPlatform::lockPhoton();

  d_positionLabel->setTextFromInteger(d_motorPosition);
  d_velocityProgress->setValue(d_motorSpeed * 10);
  int pos = 3600 - (int) (d_motorPosition * 10);
  d_positionArc->setArcStart(pos);
  d_positionArc->setArcEnd((pos - 200) % 3600);
  
  RoboticPlatform::unlockPhoton();
}

 
//======================================================================== 
// Motor::startShutdown()
//========================================================================  

void Motor::startShutdown()
{
  d_startShutdownMotorSpeed = d_motorSpeed;
}


//======================================================================== 
// Motor::getShutdownProgress
//========================================================================  

int Motor::getShutdownProgress()
{
  double progress = 1 - d_motorSpeed / d_startShutdownMotorSpeed;
  // Shutdown is complete once the motor came to a stop
  if (fabs(d_motorSpeed) < 0.0001)
    return 100;
  
  return (int) (100 * progress + Parent::getShutdownProgress()) / 2;
}


//======================================================================== 
// Motor::getNumCommands
//========================================================================  

int Motor::getNumCommands() const
{
  return Parent::getNumCommands() + 2;
}

 
//======================================================================== 
// Motor::getCommandName
//========================================================================  

const char *Motor::getCommandName(int i) const
{
  if (i < Parent::getNumCommands())
    return Parent::getCommandName(i);
  else
  {
    switch (i - Parent::getNumCommands())
    {
      case 0: return "-Stop Motor"; break;
      case 1: return "Rotate Left"; break;
      default: return 0;
    }
  }
}

 
//======================================================================== 
// Motor::doCommand
//========================================================================  

void Motor::doCommand(int i)
{
  if (i < Parent::getNumCommands())
  {
    Parent::doCommand(i);
    return;
  }
  else
  {
    switch (i - Parent::getNumCommands())
    {
      case 0: d_motorSpeed = 0; break;
      case 1: d_motorSpeed = 5; break;
    }
  }
  
  return;
}

 
//======================================================================== 
// Motor::getNumAdditionalThreads
//========================================================================  

int Motor::getNumAdditionalThreads()
{
  return Parent::getNumAdditionalThreads() + 1;
}

 
//======================================================================== 
// Motor::thread
//========================================================================  

void *Motor::thread(int num)
{
  if (num != Parent::getNumAdditionalThreads())
    Parent::thread(num);
    
  // Execute the additional thread. This should be done in real-time
  // for the motor, but is done here with inexact timing for
  // demonstration purposes
  
  // Loop to simulate the motor
  while (1)
  {
    // Very very simplified motor dynamics just for demonstration

    if (fabs(d_motorSpeed) > 15)
    {
      if (d_objectStatus.isStatusOk())
      {
        d_objectStatus.setStatusError()
          << "The motor overheated and is about to explode. Please" << endl
          << "bring a bucket of water and cool the motor down." << endl;
      }
    }
//    else
//      d_objectStatus.setStatusOk();
      
    // Friction
    if (d_motorSpeed > 0)
      d_motorSpeed -= 0.005;

    if (d_motorSpeed < 0.00000001)
      d_motorSpeed = 0;   // Inaccuracy of math lib
      
    // Position     
    d_motorPosition += d_motorSpeed / 50;
    if (d_motorPosition > 360)
      d_motorPosition -= 360;
    if (d_motorPosition < 0)
      d_motorPosition += 360;
    
    delay (1);
  }
  
  return 0;
}

 
//======================================================================== 
// Motor::create3DModel
//========================================================================  

void Motor::create3DModel()
{
  Parent::create3DModel();
  registerNode("motorPosition", &d_motorPosition, 3.14159 / 180);
}


//======================================================================== 
// main
//========================================================================  
 
int main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
  RoboticPlatform::init(argc, argv);
  
  Motor *motor[3];
  for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++)
    motor[i] = 0;
    
  motor[0] = new Motor("First Motor");
  motor[0]->setMotorSpeed(50);

  int currentMotor = 0;

  while (1)
  {
    cout << endl
         << "Menu: [1] Select Motor 1" << endl
         << "      [2] Select Motor 2" << endl
         << "      [3] Select Motor 3" << endl
         << "      [+] Increase Speed" << endl
         << "      [i] Object Info" << endl
         << "      [m] Move Motor" << endl
         << "      [d] Remove Motor" << endl
         << "      [e] Exit" << endl
         << endl
         << "Current Motor is: " << currentMotor + 1 << endl << endl;
        
    cout << "==> ";
    fflush(stdout);
    char ch;
    cin >> ch;
    cout << endl;
    
    switch (ch)
    {
      case '1':
      case '2':
      case '3':
        currentMotor = ch - '1';
        // Create motor if it does not exist yet.
        if (motor[currentMotor] == 0)
        {
          char name[100];
          cout << "Creating motor.. Name: ";
          cin >> name;
          motor[currentMotor] = new Motor(name);
          motor[currentMotor]->setMotorSpeed(10);
        }
        break;
      case '+':
      {
        double speed = motor[currentMotor]->getMotorSpeed();
        motor[currentMotor]->setMotorSpeed(speed + 5);
        break;
      }
      case 'm':
      {
        double x, y, z;
        cout << "Input position (x y z): ";
        cin >> x >> y >> z;
        motor[currentMotor]->setTransform(translation(x, y ,z));
        break;
      }
      case 'd':
        cout << "Shutting down " << motor[currentMotor]->getName() << endl;
        delete motor[currentMotor];
        motor[currentMotor] = 0;  // Indicate that motor is gone.
        break;
      case 'i':
      {
        motor[currentMotor]->outputInfo();
        break;
      }
      case 'e':
        return 0;
    }
  }
}

void setSimulationModeOn ( ) [virtual]
 

Switches the object in simulation mode. In simulation mode, the object does not access any hardware. Instead, the behavior of the hardware is simulated. The base class PhysicalObject just sets an internal flag to true. The derived class can override this behavior, but needs to call the setSimulationModeOn() function of the parent class.

Reimplemented in DefaultGripper, DefaultManipulator, DefaultOnOffTool, and DefaultToolChanger.

void setSimulationModeOff ( ) [virtual]
 

Disables the simulation mode. If the simulation mode is disabled, the hardware associated with the object is accessed. The base class PhysicalObject just sets an internal flag to false. The derived class can override this behavior, but needs to call the setSimulationModeOff() function of the parent class.

Reimplemented in DefaultGripper, DefaultManipulator, DefaultOnOffTool, and DefaultToolChanger.

bool isSimulationModeOn ( )
 

Queries if the object operates in simulation mode. The base class PhysicalObject just returns an internal flag. The derived class can override this behavior.

Returns:
true Object is in simulation mode, false Object operates the hardware.

const char * get3DModelFileName ( )
 

Returns the filename of the 3D model file. By default, this is <ClassName>.wrl. This default can be overridden by specifying the entry "modelFile <filename>" in the global configuration, under the section of the object.

Returns:
The filename of the 3D model.

SoNode * get3DModel ( )
 

Returns a pointer to the root node of the Open Inventor tree of the object's 3D model.

Returns:
A pointer to the root node of the Open Inventor tree, 0 if no 3D model has been created yet.

void create3DModel ( ) [virtual]
 

This function creates the 3D model of the object as an Open Inventor object tree. The pointer to the root of the created object tree can be determined by calling get3DModel().

The base class loads the VRML file with the filename that is returned by get3DModelFileName().

A derived class can reimplement this function to create the 3D model without the help of PhysicalObject::create3DModel (e.g., by creating Open Inventor model primitives). The derived class must call set3DModel() with the root node of the Open Inventor tree.

A derived class usually reimplements this function to implement animation of an Open Inventor object. Do do so, call PhysicalObject::create3DModel() first, then use registerNode();

Returns:
A pointer to the root node of the Open Inventor tree.

Example: 

     void Motor::create3DModel()
     {
       PhysicalObject::create3DModel();
    
       registerNode("motorAngle", &d_motorAngle);
     }

Reimplemented in DefaultGripper, and Manipulator.

void update3DModel ( ) [virtual]
 

This function is continuously called by the Scene Viewer. It updates specific nodes of the Open Inventor object tree (e.g., rotation nodes) with the current state of the object. The base class updates registered nodes, see registerNode().

Reimplemented in Manipulator.

void set3DModel ( SoNode * modelRoot ) [protected]
 

Allows a derived class to set the root node of the Open Inventor tree of the object's 3D model. This function is usually called from a reimplemented create3DModel().

Parameters:
modelRoot   A pointer to the new root node of the Open Inventor tree of the object's model.

Example: 

     void CubeObject::create3DModel()
     {
       SoNode *cube = new SoCube();
       set3DModel(cube);
     }

void registerNode ( const char * nodeName,
double * value,
double factor = 1,
double offset = 0,
int axis = e_zAxis ) [protected]
 

Registers a SoTranslation or a SoRotationXYZ node for automatic update. Everytime PhysicalObject::update3DModel() is called, all registered nodes are updated by value * factor + offset. A derived class only needs to register the appropriate nodes by calling registerNode() from the get3DModel() function, and the update is performed automatically. If the animation of the 3D model by using SoTranslation and SoRotationXYZ is not sufficient, the derived class has to do the animation manually in a reimplemented update3DModel().

registerNode() should be called from the get3DModel() function of a derived class. It must not be called before PhysicalObject::get3DModel is called.

Parameters:
nodeName   The name of the node, as specified in the VRML file.
value   A pointer to the variable that determines the node value.
factor   A factor that is multiplied with value
offset   An offset added to value * factor.
axis   This parameter is only meaningful for translation nodes. It specifies the axis of translation.

void setDisplayOff ( )
 

Hides the object in the Scene Viewer. Default is solid display.

bool isDisplayOff ( ) const
 

Returns whether the object is hidden in the Scene Viewer. is turned off.

Returns:
true: Object is hidden, false: Object is not hidden.

void setDisplaySolid ( )
 

Displays the object in the Scene Viewer with filled and shaded surfaces. This is the default display mode.

bool isDisplaySolid ( ) const
 

Returns whether the object is displayed in solid mode.

Returns:
true: Object is displayed in solid mode, false: Object is displayed in another mode or hidden.

void setDisplayWireframe ( )
 

Displays the object in the Scene Viewer with the edges only (wire frame mode). Default is solid display.

bool isDisplayWireframe ( ) const
 

Returns whether the object is displayed in wire frame mode.

Returns:
true: Object is displayed in wire frame mode false: Object is displayed in another mode or hidden.

void setConnection ( PhysicalObject & objectIAmMountedAt,
const char * connectionNodeName = "DefaultConnectionNode" ) [virtual]
 

Establishes a new object connection. For example, this can be used to indicate that a gripper is mounted on a manipulator. The connection point(s) are nodes of class SoGroup or a derived class in the Open Inventor tree, identified by node names. At least one node should identify itself as a connection point by specifying the name "DefaultConnectionNode". It is possible to specify additional nodes as connection points with any names. When establishing the connection, the name of the node used as a connection point is specified by the parameter connectionNodeName.

The display of the Scene Viewer reflects object connections. The mounting location and orientation is specified with setTransform().

If the programmer tries to establish a circular connection (e.g., object A is connected to B, B is connected to C, and C is connected to A), no connection is established and the object status is set to error.

Parameters:
objectIAmMountedAt   The object where this object is mounted at.
connectionNodeName   The name of the node in the Open Inventor tree of objectIAmMountedAt that specifies the connection point.

Example: 

     Gripper gripper;
     Puma560 puma;
    
     gripper.setConnection(puma);

void removeConnection ( ) [virtual]
 

Removes the connection of this object to any other. The object is now free in the space, at the absolute position and orientation specfied with setTransform().

PhysicalObject * getConnectedObject ( ) const
 

Determines the connected object.

Returns:
A pointer to the connected object, or 0 if this object is not connected to any other object.

const char * getConnectionNodeName ( ) const
 

Determines the name of the node in the Open Inventor tree that specifies the connection point of the current connection.

Returns:
A pointer to the node name or 0 if there is no connection.

void setTransform ( const Transform & transform ) [virtual]
 

Sets the transform that specifies position and orientation of the object (if no object connection is present), or the position and orientation relative to the object at which this object is mounted on (in an object connection exists).

Parameters:
transform   The transform specifying position and orientation.

Example: 

     Puma560 puma;
    
     // Place Puma at x=40 with an angle of 30 degrees
     puma.setTransform(translation(40, 0, 0) * zRotation(30));

Transform getTransform ( ) const [virtual]
 

Returns the transform that specfies position and orientation of the object (if no object connection is present), or the position and orientation relative to the object at which this object is mounted on (in an object connection exists).

Returns:
The transform specifying position and orientation.

void finishInit ( ) [protected, virtual]
 

This function is called from the init() functions as the last step right before the object is added to the object manager. At this point, the configuration of the object is setup, the QMotor control program (if existing) is started, and all the threads are started up.

This class performs no action. A derived class needs to first call the finishInit() function of the parent class. A derived class could e.g. use this function to synchronize with the other threads.

Reimplemented from RoboticObject.

Reimplemented in DefaultManipulator.

void readGlobalConfiguration ( Config * config ) [protected, virtual]
 

Sets up the configuration of the object from the global configuration file. This class reads the simulation mode (entry simulationMode), the display properties (entry display), the 3D model filename (entry modelFile) and the object transform (entry position/orientation) from the configuration file.

See also:
RoboticObject::readGlobalConfiguration()
Parameters:
config   A pointer to the global configuration.

Reimplemented from RoboticObject.

Reimplemented in DefaultGripper, DefaultManipulator, DefaultOnOffTool, DefaultToolChanger, and Puma560.
